entry.summary: 今年 Apple Intelligence 和 iPhone 屏幕共享所发生的事情正是我预计 Apple 创建的与 iOS 集成的每一项新产品或服务都会发生的事情：它们将迟到，或者永远不会出现在欧盟。
entry.content:
8 月底， Apple 又宣布了几项 DMA 合规性变更。它们值得详细研究。

强制浏览器选择屏幕的更改

欧盟浏览器选择屏幕中提供的浏览器的开发人员将向查看选择屏幕的用户显示有关其浏览器的附加信息，并将获得有关选择屏幕性能的更多数据。更新后的选择屏幕将向所有将 Safari 设置为默认浏览器的欧盟用户显示。有关浏览器选择屏幕的更改的详细信息，请查看关于欧盟的浏览器选择屏幕。

新变化的一些选择细节：

  • 所有使用 Safari 作为默认浏览器的用户（包括在更新之前已经看到选择屏幕的用户）将在安装今年晚些时候推出的更新后首次启动 Safari 时看到选择屏幕。

  • 如果用户已经将 Safari 以外的浏览器设置为默认浏览器，则不会显示选择屏幕。

  • 选择屏幕将在每个设备上显示一次，而不是每个用户一次。

  • 当迁移到新设备时，如果（且仅当）用户之前选择的默认浏览器是 Safari，则用户将需要重新选择默认浏览器（即与 iOS 中的其他设置不同，用户选择的默认浏览器不会被迁移）如果那个选择是 Safari）。

我明白，这个强制选择屏幕的全部意义在于，因为用 DMA 的话说，iOS 是一个指定的“把关”平台，因此推测苹果通过将 Safari 与操作系统捆绑在一起并将其设为默认值，从而不公平地获得了 Safari 的优势。因此，从欧盟委员会的角度来看，一些相当多的 iOS 用户使用 Safari只是因为它是捆绑的和默认的，并且更喜欢和/或获得更好的服务 - 甚至只是同等的服务 - 使用另一个 Web 浏览器作为默认浏览器。因此，Safari 受到了不同的对待。它不仅仅是 11 个浏览器列表中的另一个浏览器。它是唯一一个用户将被迫再次选择的浏览器，即使他们已经在 iOS 17.4 或更高版本中选择了它。它是唯一一款用户在迁移到新 iPhone 或 iPad 时被迫再次选择的浏览器。除了反复激怒拥有多个 iOS 设备的 Safari 用户之外，强制每个设备而不是每个用户使用此屏幕到底有什么意义呢？

这些限制在什么时候会惩罚想要使用 Safari 的 Safari 用户？我想说，欧盟委员会通过将这些规则强加给苹果公司，已经跨越了这一点。另一个细节：

  • 在将浏览器设置为默认浏览器之前，用户需要滚动浏览浏览器选项的完整列表。

您知道在某些“条款和条件”协议屏幕中，您只有在一直滚动到几乎没有人真正阅读的法律术语底部后才能“同意”吗？这就是浏览器选择屏幕现在必须工作的方式。 iOS 中几乎没有任何东西是这样工作的，我怀疑不少在随机列表中找到自己喜欢的浏览器的用户会发现在选择浏览器后“什么也没有发生”感到非常困惑。这是法律规定的不良交互设计。

如果 Safari 当前位于用户的 Dock 或主屏幕的第一页上，并且用户从选择屏幕中选择了设备上当前未安装的浏览器，则所选浏览器将替换用户 Dock 或主屏幕中的 Safari 图标。主屏幕。

17 年来，iOS 主屏幕始终保持空间感。无论应用程序放置在主屏幕上的哪个位置，它都会保留在那里。现在，显然，EC 的反对意见是，苹果公司在用户 Dock 中默认放置了 Safari，从而不公平地赋予了 Safari 特权，并且他们正在寻求为在选择屏幕上选择 Safari 以外的浏览器的任何用户取消此特权。但肯定有一些用户会后悔他们的选择。或者只是尝试打开 Safari，同时尝试其他浏览器作为新的默认浏览器。但现在，与 iOS 17 年来的工作方式不同，Safari 图标将不再保留在原来的位置。还值得注意的是，iOS Dock 中的应用程序不显示其名称，仅显示其图标。肯定有许多满意的 Safari 用户甚至不知道“Safari”是什么——他们只知道蓝色罗盘图标。他们知道，每当他们打开电子邮件或短信中的 URL 时，这些 URL 都会在他们完全熟悉的界面中打开。当然，浏览器选择屏幕确实会显示浏览器的图标，但仍然如此。这是法律规定的混淆。

呈现给用户的浏览器列表与苹果之前的浏览器选择屏幕基本保持不变：欧盟各成员国下载次数最多的 11 款浏览器。因此，27 个欧盟国家都有自己的名单。 Apple 在其支持页面底部列出了每个国家/地区当前的浏览器。

以下是所有包含的浏览器的单个列表，按它们包含在 27 个欧盟国家中的数量排序。对于所有 27 个国家/地区包含的 9 个浏览器，我已随机化顺序：

  • Chrome、谷歌有限责任公司 (27)
  • Edge，微软公司 (27)
  • Opera、Opera 软件 AS (27)
  • 勇敢，勇敢的软件 (27)
  • 苹果 Safari (27)
  • DuckDuckGo、DuckDuckGo 公司 (27)
  • 阿罗哈，阿罗哈移动 (27)
  • 洋葱浏览器，迈克·蒂加斯 (27)
  • 火狐、Mozilla (27)
  • 你，SuSea Inc. (23)
  • 埃科西亚, 埃科西亚 (17)
  • 维瓦尔第、维瓦尔第技术 (13)
  • Web@Work、MobileIron (10)
  • 网络、AirWatch LLC (5)
  • 想要，Q想要 (3)
  • 浏览器，Maple Media Apps LLC (3)
  • Access，黑莓公司 (3)
  • Seznam.cz、Seznam.cz 为 (2)
  • Presearch，Presearch.org 全球有限公司 (1)
  • Avast 安全浏览器、AVAST 软件 (1)

我熟悉所有 27 个国家/地区的 9 种浏览器中的大多数，您可能也熟悉。但我从未听说过Aloha或Onion Browser ，尤其是 Onion Browser 来自个人开发者 Mike Tigas。 （ Onion 浏览器也因开源而脱颖而出。）Aloha 和 Onion 都被宣传为“注重隐私”，对于连接到Tor的 Onion 浏览器来说尤其如此。 Aloha 包括内置广告拦截和跳过地理围栏的 VPN。

因此，11 个位置中的 9 个被整个欧盟的相同流行浏览器占据。在其他 11 种浏览器中，我唯一听说过的是Ecosia ，它与 DuckDuckGo 一样，作为搜索引擎而广为人知（并且与 DuckDuckGo 一样，它位于 Safari 在大多数国家/地区提供的非常短的搜索引擎列表中世界各地）。 1

您是否知道BlackBerry 开发了一款 iOS 浏览器，并且它在爱尔兰、波兰和瑞典非常受欢迎？我没有。 （你知道黑莓仍然存在吗？我不知道。）

这个强制浏览器选择屏幕的全部目的是为了吸引 Safari 用户并让他们尽可能轻松地切换默认浏览器。但这样的用户有多少，谁应该切换？有多少用户了解什么是网络浏览器、什么是默认网络浏览器，目前默认使用 Safari，但看到这个选择屏幕并想“哦，这太棒了，我不知道我可以切换到一个对于这些其他浏览器，我会这样做...... ”？我确信存在一些这样的用户。但我也确信还有其他用户不太了解网络浏览器是什么，不知道他们当前使用的浏览器（也许已经使用了十多年）被命名为“Safari” ，并且不知道如何撤消他们在此浏览器选择屏幕上可能犯的错误。已经知道如何更改默认 iOS Web 浏览器的用户不需要这个强制选择屏幕；不知道如何更改默认浏览器的用户可能会陷入错误或后悔的选择。选择Safari，您将再次看到此浏览器选择屏幕；选择其他任何东西，也许只是为了好玩，你就再也见不到它了。

我的猜测是，也许与直觉相反，这个强制浏览器选择屏幕的最大受益者将是谷歌浏览器，我认为它是当今世界上最具主导地位的软件垄断者。已经知道自己想要使用非 Safari 浏览器并将其设置为默认浏览器的用户甚至不会看到此屏幕。想要使用 Safari 并且知道自己想要使用 Safari 的用户只会被这个屏幕（反复）惹恼。但对这个屏幕感到困惑的非技术用户（我保证仅在欧盟就有数百万这样的用户）肯定会选择他们听说过的浏览器，并希望他们做出了正确的选择。 Chrome 是迄今为止世界上使用最广泛的网络浏览器，对于某些用户来说，这是他们唯一听说过的浏览器。

iOS 17.4 在 3 月份发布后不久——这是第一个具有 DMA 合规功能的版本，也是第一个为欧盟 Safari 用户提供强制浏览器选择屏幕的版本——有一些关于第三方浏览器用户数量增加的报道。TechCrunch 的这篇文章也许是最好的例子。这些收益主要以贝索斯的数字来报告——相对收益，没有绝对数字。 Aloha 浏览器“表示 3 月份欧盟用户增长了 250%”。 Opera 报告称，“从 3 月 3 日到 4 月 4 日，iOS 上选择其浏览器作为默认浏览器的用户增长了 39%”——但这低于iOS 在欧盟实施强制选择屏幕之前的上个月 164% 的增长。报告实际数字的浏览器是 Brave：

“今年 3 月份，随着新的浏览器面板的推出，Brave 在欧盟 iOS 上的每日安装量从 7,500 左右增加到 11,000 左右，”公司发言人表示。 “在过去的几天里，我们的每日安装量达到了 14,000 次，创下历史新高，几乎是我们预选屏幕数量的两倍。”

自四月份以来，我就看到了有关小型浏览器的浏览器选择屏幕持续“成功”的消息。我想这在欧盟迫使苹果做出进一步让步的过程中发挥了一定作用——尤其是向所有已经在 iOS 17.4、17.5 或 17.6 中选择了 Safari 的欧盟 iOS 用户重新呈现浏览器选择屏幕。但我认为事实是显而易见的：绝大多数 iOS 用户使用 Safari 是因为他们想要这样做，从欣赏 Safari 功能、UI 和隐私的见多识广的书呆子，到只知道自己喜欢这种体验的非技术典型用户与苹果的第一方应用程序和服务生态系统。

但无论这个浏览器选择屏幕对欧盟 iOS 浏览器的使用有何影响，我都认为 Chrome 不会从中受益最多。对于旨在监管“大型看门人”的法律来说，这似乎是一个反常的结果。 Chrome在全球所有网络浏览市场中占据 65% 的市场份额，比 iOS、Android 或 Windows 具有更大的垄断地位，唯一拥有两位数市场份额 (19%) 的其他浏览器是 Safari——欧盟委员会正试图将这款浏览器引导用户远离。

“默认”应用程序

回到苹果在其开发者新闻网站上的声明：

对于欧盟用户，iOS 18 和 iPadOS 18 还将在“设置”中包含一个新的“默认应用程序”部分，其中列出了每个用户可用的默认应用程序。在未来的软件更新中，用户将获得拨打电话号码、发送消息、翻译文本、导航、管理密码、键盘和垃圾电话过滤器的新默认设置。要了解更多信息，请查看在欧盟分发的应用程序的更新。

此外，欧盟用户现在可以删除 App Store、消息、照片、相机和 Safari 应用程序。

请记住，至少自 iOS 14（四年前）以来，我们已经能够从主屏幕中删除我们想要的任何应用程序。只是某些重要的系统应用程序无法删除- 当从主屏幕中删除时，它们仍然可以在应用程序库中使用。应用程序库是 iOS 的一个重要补充，也许应该早几年出现。但欧盟委员会现在要求苹果公司能够删除这些应用程序。这对于 App Store 应用程序来说尤其棘手，因为人们可以通过 App Store 重新安装已删除的默认 iOS 应用程序。据推测，App Store 应用程序将可以通过“设置”重新安装，这是仅有的两个不可删除的应用程序之一。 2

那些为这些变化欢呼雀跃的人忽略的是，删除这些核心系统应用程序并不能神奇地使 iOS 成为一个模块化系统。 Apple 尚未宣布为欧盟的第三方应用程序提供任何类型的 API 来处理 SMS（现在是 RCS）蜂窝短信。我不知道删除消息的用户收到的短信会发生什么情况。 3

同样，苹果还没有宣布任何用于模块化照片存储的 API。在撰写本文时，删除系统照片和相机应用程序的用户将无法选择其他应用程序来处理照片存储。拍摄的照片和视频仍会进入系统照片库。用户之前存储在设备上的图像仍将保留在系统照片库中。只是苹果不会有一个应用程序来显示系统照片库。我的理解是，在幕后，照片和相机都不是传统意义上的真正的“应用程序”。它们只是低级系统框架的薄包装。相同的系统级框架允许第三方应用程序访问系统照片库。苹果似乎并没有被迫允许第三方软件取代这些低级系统框架。他们只是被迫允许用户“删除”这些将自己作为应用程序呈现给用户的薄包装程序。但系统照片库的实际工作方式保持不变。这就像如果 Mac 让你删除 Finder — 文件系统仍然存在，但用户将无法浏览它。

一个具有基本模块化设计的操作系统，以及允许几乎每个系统组件被第三方软件替换的 API，听起来是一个好主意。但实际上没有一个主要操作系统是这样构建的。 iOS当然不是。因此，要求苹果允许“删除”照片和相机等应用程序纯粹是轻易的，并且暴露了欧盟委员会的技术无知。发表这些言论的 EC 官员显然不知道 iOS 的实际工作原理。他们只知道他们能看到什么。 iOS 附带了很多应用程序。他们所关心的是，现在欧盟的用户将能够删除这些应用程序。

当然，许多摄影师更喜欢使用第三方相机应用程序而不是苹果的系统相机应用程序。但 iOS 长期以来一直为使用第三方相机应用程序提供丰富的支持，并且在 iOS 18 中，这种支持变得更好，用户很快就能够配置以前仅用于启动系统相机应用程序的锁屏按钮。 （迄今为止专用于系统手电筒“应用程序”的按钮也是如此 - 也可以在 iOS 18 中配置。）添加到锁定屏幕的相机应用程序甚至在 iOS 18 中获得特殊权限- 对于全球所有用户，而不仅仅是在欧盟。即使是第三方相机应用程序的开发人员也认为删除系统相机应用程序没有任何意义。

那么谁会从能够彻底“删除”照片和相机应用程序中受益呢？据我所知，只有患有强迫症的人才会担心将它们从主屏幕中删除后，它们仍然列在应用程序库中。我不清楚欧盟用户是否能够删除照片和相机等应用程序，即使他们没有安装任何第三方摄影应用程序，这将使他们的 iPhone 处于无法获取新照片的状态。照片或查看现有照片。这就是表演性调节。这些可删除的应用程序都不会增加竞争；它只会增加用户产生深刻困惑的可能性。

需要明确的是，就像浏览器选择屏幕一样，我认为苹果的这些“默认应用程序”和“可删除应用程序”合规性让步不会有多大影响。按照设计，在 iOS 中删除应用程序是一个多步骤的过程，甚至需要长时间按住才能进入抖动模式。即使是新手用户也不会意外删除应用程序。但用户确实没有可衡量的需求来删除必要的系统应用程序。那么要求苹果支持有什么意义呢？就为了看公司跳舞？

我的意思是为什么停在这里？为什么不强制允许用户删除整个操作系统？

Apple Intelligence 和 iPhone 镜像

当苹果在 6 月份 WWDC 几周后宣布，今年最大的两个功能——Apple Intelligence 和 iPhone Mirroring——今年可能在欧盟仍然无法使用，“由于数字市场法案带来的监管不确定性” ，DMA支持者怀疑恶意是动机。我当时引用了伊恩·贝特里奇的话，并将再次引用他的话，因为我认为他的反应集中体现了这一观点：

那么，Apple，Apple Intelligence 违反了 DMA 的哪些部分？因为除非你能真正告诉我们——在这种情况下，我们显然对你所提出的有关其运作方式的一些说法存在一些问题——否则你就是在胡说八道，只是想在欧盟方面获得一些影响力。哪个是蒂姆？

我绝对保证人们会接受这样的说法：“好吧，多亏了 DMA，你无法让 Apple Intelligence 工作！！”没有真正询问任何关于它违反了什么的问题，因为“苹果说的是，他们不会撒谎”

我在 6 月份对 Betteridge 的回应是成立的，而且随着苹果公司的这些最新让步，我看起来更有先见之明。

由于 DMA 特别适用于 Apple，我认为 DMA 支持者的错误在于他们并不是真正的 DMA 支持者，而是 App Store 的反对者。他们强烈反对苹果对 iOS 上所有第三方软件的严格控制，包括（如果不是特别的话）对通过本机应用程序访问的应用程序、游戏和数字内容的支付的控制。因此他们认可并支持 DMA，因为 DMA 打破了这种控制。由于 DMA，欧盟现在存在 iOS 第三方应用程序市场，Apple 自己的 App Store 中的应用程序可以选择新条款来使用自己的支付处理（在欧盟）。因此，从苹果 App Store 反对者的角度来看，DMA 总体上一定是一个净利，因为他们认为 DMA 的意义（至少与苹果有关）是为了打破 App Store 对所有 iOS 的束缚。第三方原生软件。

但这根本不是 DMA 的重点。这只是它的副产品之一。这是一个非常引人注目的副产品，因为支持替代应用市场和替代支付处理是苹果从今年 3 月开始需要遵守的法规。如果您对 Apple 的个人不满是 App Store 模式，那么您很容易得出 DMA 旨在打破该模式的结论。如果您认为 DMA 主要是为了打破 App Store 模式，那么很容易看出您认为 Apple Intelligence 和 iPhone Mirroring 会引发任何合规性问题的说法是无稽之谈，因此向欧盟用户（以及第三个）保留这些功能功能、SharePlay 屏幕共享的增强）一定是苹果方面的恶意。

我认为，苹果公司向欧盟用户隐瞒这些功能是出于恶意，希望欧盟 iOS 用户反对 DMA，并以某种方式要求欧盟代表废除或修改该功能。但这很容易。苹果公司对 DMA 提出了反对意见，克雷格·费德里吉 (Craig Federighi) 于 2021 年在葡萄牙里斯本网络峰会上发表的主题演讲就是最好的例证，但无济于事。 DMA 在欧洲议会以压倒性优势获得通过：588 票赞成，11 票反对，31 票弃权。这是大陆的法律。

苹果出于恶意而向欧盟公民拒绝提供主要的 iOS 功能是没有意义的。即使你认为苹果公司的自身利益高于一切，但他们最大的自身利益就是销售新 iPhone。今年 iPhone 16 机型中最大的新功能将是 Apple Intelligence，而 iOS 18 中最好的新功能是 iPhone 屏幕共享。这些功能将有助于 iPhone 的销售，但至少今年不会在欧盟销售。

关键是DMA并不是针对App Store模式的针对性攻击。这是对整个集成理念的广泛攻击。整合是苹果的全部运作方式。硬件和软件的集成旨在协同工作。不同设备之间的集成——连续性——旨在协同工作。

另外：同一设备上不同应用程序之间的集成。 Safari 不仅仅是 Apple 的网络浏览器。它是 Apple 设计的 Web浏览器，用于在 iOS 上以iOS 方式（以及在 MacOS 上以Macintosh 方式）执行操作。如果作为用户，您按照 Apple 的方式做事 — 拥有多台 Apple 设备、使用 iCloud 进行同步、使用 Safari 作为网络浏览器 — 您将获得集成体验，可以在设备 A 上访问设备 B 上打开的选项卡、共享所有设备之间的浏览历史记录和书签，以及对系统范围服务和功能的支持。新出厂 iPhone 上的 Apple 默认应用程序旨在协同工作并一致地呈现自己。这并不是说没有人应该使用第三方应用程序来替代苹果自己的应用程序。当然不是。当然，几乎每一位《大胆火球》的读者都使用一个或多个替代苹果应用程序的第三方应用程序。我用了几个。但内置的苹果应用程序加在一起就构成了苹果定义的体验。这些确实是大多数非专家用户应该使用的应用程序。最好的第三方替代品——比如Fantastical （日历）、 Cardhop （通讯录）和Bear （笔记）——可以无缝融入 Apple 的整体体验。它们是感觉与第一方体验融为一体的第三方应用程序。

从欧盟委员会的角度来看，一切都应该模块化和商品化。这就是他们对“竞争”的理想。在“手机”和“平板电脑”领域的主导地位不应让制造这些设备的公司在网络浏览器、电子邮件客户端、消息传递或相机应用程序市场上占据优势。但从苹果的角度来看，iPhone 不仅仅是一款“手机”，一款商品化的硬件。这就是为什么该公司通常避免发表文章，在谈论和撰写文章时不提及“iPhone”，而只提及“iPhone”。对于苹果来说，iPhone 是一种综合体验，包括硬件、软件和服务，全部由苹果自己设计和制造。

现在我们有证据表明 DMA 要求 Apple 允许删除除“设置”（以及 iPhone 上的“电话”）之外的所有应用程序，并允许为从非接触式支付到密码管理、地图到翻译的所有内容设置第三方默认值甚至对于键盘来说，显然 EC 也可能要求用户能够为 Apple Intelligence 指定第三方“默认”AI 语言模型。不仅仅是苹果目前与 OpenAI 独家合作提供的可选“世界知识”层，还有具有语义个人知识的 Apple Intelligence 基础层。 Apple Intelligence 并不是这样设计的。它不是一个模块或一个“应用程序”。它是系统软件的深度集成层。面对欧盟委员会的决定，即苹果要么将所有 Apple Intelligence 向第三方 AI 开放（包括苹果本身未经审查的 AI 系统），要么永远不在欧盟提供 Apple Intelligence，我认为苹果会选择永远不在欧盟提供。欧盟。

至于 iPhone 屏幕共享，DMA 不允许网守平台优先选择网守本身的其他产品或服务。 iPhone 屏幕共享仅适用于 iPhone 和 Mac（Apple 制造的计算机）之间。这是违反 DMA 的——或者至少 EC 可以明确裁定它违反 DMA。

如果 DMA 于 10 年前生效，我认为 Apple Watch 不会在欧盟上市，除非欧盟委员会表示允许。 AirPods 也是如此，与标准蓝牙相比，它与 Apple 设备的配对方式要优越得多，但也是专有的。 iPhone 和其他 Apple 设备之间任何第三方设备无法使用的集成都可能被裁定违反 DMA。我认为，根据 DMA 的信函，EC应该裁定所有此类整合均属违规。

随着时间的推移，这种不确定性可能会变得清晰。也许欧盟委员会会裁定 Apple Intelligence 和/或 iPhone 屏幕共享不违反 DMA，并且 Apple 可以在欧盟提供这些功能（就像它们目前存在的那样）。就像，也许 EC 委员自己真的只是想打破 App Store 模式，仅此而已。但欧盟委员会副主席玛格丽特·维斯塔格 (Margrethe Vestager) 明确认为，Apple Intelligence 具有反竞争性，因此违反了 DMA。她在 7 月份的欧洲论坛上发表讲话时表示：

我觉得很有趣的是，他们说我们现在将在没有义务促进竞争的地方部署人工智能。我认为这是最令人震惊的公开声明，他们 100% 知道这是在他们已经拥有据点的情况下阻碍竞争的另一种方式。

她非常明确地表示，她认为苹果“有义务在 DMA 下与人工智能展开竞争”。 Apple Intelligence 根本不存在竞争。这里必须付出一些东西。

欧盟委员会的明显期望是，由于欧盟规模如此之大，对世界如此重要，苹果公司——以及 DMA 的其他目标“看门人”——将屈服于其意愿，并从此在设计其产品和服务时考虑到 DMA。在堆栈的所有层，模块化胜于集成。欧盟内部市场专员蒂埃里·布雷顿 (Thierry Breton)在 7 月份打趣道：“苹果的新口号应该是‘与众不同’。”

但欧盟并没有那么大，也没有那么重要。欧盟委员会被自大妄想所困扰。今年 Apple Intelligence 和 iPhone 屏幕共享所发生的事情正是我预计 Apple 创建的与 iOS 集成的每一项新产品或服务都会发生的事情：它们将迟到，或者永远不会出现在欧盟。 Apple 创造的所有新产品和服务都与 iOS 集成，因此 Apple 的几乎所有新产品都会迟到或永远不会出现在欧盟。

虽然这不是 DMA 的初衷，但这就是 DMA 的实际效果。

  1. DuckDuckGo 和 Ecosia 都是 Safari 中支持的搜索引擎的名称，而网络浏览器是 Safari 的独立替代品，这一事实肯定会让非技术用户感到困惑。我并不是说 DuckDuckGo 或 Ecosia 不应该制作自己的浏览器，或者应该以不同的方式命名它们，但想象一下，如果谷歌没有将他们的浏览器命名为“Chrome”，而是将其命名为“Google”，会产生怎样的混乱。 ↩︎

  2. 另一个剩余的不可删除的应用程序是电话，我认为不能删除它，以保持遵守法律，要求所有手机，无论是否有有效的 SIM 卡，都能够拨打紧急服务电话（例如，这里的 911）我们）。 ↩︎︎

  3. 还要注意的是，虽然 Android 始终提供 API 来允许第三方应用程序处理 SMS 蜂窝消息传递，但支持安全 E2EE 的流行消息传递应用程序却避开了它。 Signal 在 Android 上支持短信已有 10 多年，但在 2022 年宣布将取消短信支持，原因很充分，他们希望避免对加密内容（使用 Signal 协议的所有消息）和未加密内容产生任何可能的混淆（通过 SMS 发送的所有消息）在 Signal 应用程序中。 WhatsApp 是欧盟大部分地区最受欢迎的消息平台，但 Android 上从未支持短信。 Android 上剩余的第三方短信应用程序看起来像是一堆劣质广告软件和诈骗软件。 ↩︎︎

当欧盟在2018年颁布GDPR时，高管和安全专业人员焦急地等待着如何执行法律。然后他们一直在等待...等待...但是欧洲伟大的隐私镇压从未到来。有一阵子似乎是您被GDPR罚款拍打的唯一方法就是做一些真正令人震惊的事情或被命名为Mark Zuckerberg。 （或最好是两者。）

但是，押注您太大或太小而无法被GDPR注意到的日子已经结束。最近，欧盟成员国（加上英国）已开始对各种规模的数据控制者采取行动，从大型（亚马逊）到媒体（一家卡车公司）到真正的微小（西班牙公民）（其家庭安全摄像机困扰的西班牙公民）他们的邻居）。

那么，2018年至2024年之间发生了什么变化？也许最大的因素是，欧盟对将伪造的“总部”在具有友好监管机构（尤其是爱尔兰）的国家 /地区放置。但是，在过去的几年中看到了无休止的数据泄露故事，而且公众与技术的关系越来越恶化，这肯定无济于事。如今，有一种对执行的胃口，它可能会变得更糟，然后再变得更好。

如果您是IT或安全专业人员，您可能想知道该如何处理此信息。不幸的是，GDPR合规性不是您可以通过购买工具或安排培训课程来解决的事情。最好的起点是采用数据最小化政策：仅收集您真正需要的数据，包括客户和员工。

之后，您的第二个优先级必须确保拥有的数据。当然，这说起来容易做起来难，但是您可以开始做更多的事情来防止诸如受损密码之类的常见违规罪魁祸首。 （打电话给我们有偏见，但要为每个员工提供密码管理器确实是良好安全性。）您还需要监视所有数据的运行位置，因此PII不会消失在Shadow IT应用程序和不受管理的设备上。

我们将以英国信息专员约翰·爱德华兹（John Edwards）的2022年报价结束：

“最大的网络风险业务面临的不是公司以外的黑客，而是来自公司内部的自满情绪。如果您的企业没有定期监视其系统中的可疑活动，并且无法在警告中采取行动，或者没有更新软件并且无法为员工提供培训，那么您可以期望我的办公室罚款类似。”

换句话说：是时候认真对待GDPR了。

entry.title: 如何处理不必要的政治垃圾邮件文本
entry.content:
摘自Apple自己的“删除和报告垃圾”功能的文档：消息：

发件人的信息和消息发送给Apple，并将消息永久从您的iPhone中删除。

如果您不小心报告并删除消息，则可以恢复它们。

报告垃圾或垃圾邮件不能阻止发件人发送消息，但您可以阻止数字停止接收消息。

通过安德鲁·莉亚（Andrew Leahey） ，在马斯托登（Mastodon）上回应了马可（Marco Arment） 。

去年，我被民主政治运动和PAC的垃圾邮件短信淹没了。我知道为什么：因为过去，我和我的妻子都为民主政治运动做出了贡献。我在这里加上我的妻子，因为无论出于何种原因，我收到的一大部分政治短信垃圾邮件都被介绍给“艾米”，而不是我，而对她来说恰恰相反。但是：每当我曾经为政治运动或任何慈善机构捐款时，我都会密切关注任何复选框，使我可以“选择退出”任何进一步的营销传播。这似乎并不重要。商店和慈善机构在尊重这一点方面非常糟糕，但政治运动绝对是最糟糕的。

今年的几个月中，我会说，每天，每天，每周大约六个此类消息时，我都尝试使用消息的“删除和报告垃圾”功能。据我所知，这没有该死的事情。现在我看到了苹果自己的文档，我可以明白为什么。使用此功能甚至不会阻止发件人发送更多消息。

大约一个月前，我换了战术，开始用“停止”来回复所有此类消息。我通常会像这样将其发送给所有帽子，因为我很生气。直到一个月前，我一直拒绝这样做，以为在包括魔术“停止”关键字在内的这些消息完全回复，只能向发件人确认实际的人正在查看发送给我电话号码的消息。但这实际上奏效了。选举季节正在升温，但我现在的政治垃圾邮件文本较少。您的里程可能会有所不同，但是对我来说，“停止”响应有效。

另外两个观察结果：

  • 在过去的几年中，我收到的每一个不需要的短信 - 每一个都是短信，而不是iMessage。 iMessage垃圾邮件存在，但对我来说，至少这与SMS是一个晚上和差异。在这方面，我看不出RC不会比SMS那么糟糕或更糟（因为它支持更大的图像）。苹果应该让基于载体的消息传递在葡萄藤上枯萎。

  • 今年，几乎每条短信都发送给我的个人电话号码，我将其描述为“垃圾邮件”，这是一种试图让我为政治运动做出贡献的尝试。我收到我使用的信号和WhatsApp的公共电话号码发送的随机网络钓鱼文本（我鼓励您与我联系，如果您愿意的话，而不是电子邮件），但是可以预料，这些都不是消息。过去对美国的政治运动做出了贡献，这感觉不仅是惩罚。 Like anyone who gives to a political campaign is a sucker. It's absolutely infuriating. I care deeply about US politics, particularly in this ongoing Trump era, but these spam text messages absolutely have made me less willing to contribute money to campaigns and causes I believe in. Political consultants may well have analytics that show that these spams-to-people-who've-previously-donated-money-to-our-side “work”, but for me — and many of my friends — it has had the opposite effect. I've contributed significantly less money this year than in 2020 — and I now avoid ever donating small amounts to down-ballot campaigns — and the one and only reason why is that I'm annoyed that my previous contributions directly led Democratic campaigns and PACs to send me a zillion spam texts. Not only have I never, in my life, given a penny to any group whom I feel is spamming me, but this has made me gun-shy about contributing any money at all. I'll never ever give out my actual phone number or email address to any political campaign ever again. They clearly have no respect for my time and attention. I think they've talked themselves into thinking this strategy “works” because it works for some of the previous donors they spam with new solicitations, but their analytics won't show the people like me who just stop or greatly decrease their contributions without clicking any of their links. I suppose their analytics can count the “STOP” responses I've started sending, but I doubt they can correlate those “STOP”s with my drop-off in contributions.

entry.title: 'How Telegram Played Itself'
entry.content:
Casey Newton, writing at Platformer:

Telegram is often described as an “encrypted” messenger. But as Ben Thompson explains today , Telegram is not end-to-end encrypted, as rivals WhatsApp and Signal are. (Its “secret chat” feature is end-to-end encrypted, but it is not enabled on chats by default. The vast majority of chats on Telegram are not secret chats.) That means Telegram can look at the contents of private messages, making it vulnerable to law enforcement requests for that data.

Anticipating these requests, Telegram created a kind of jurisdictional obstacle course for law enforcement that (it says) none of them have successfully navigated so far.From the FAQ again :

为了保护端到端加密未覆盖的数据，Telegram 使用分布式基础设施。云聊天数据存储在全球多个数据中心，这些数据中心由分布在不同司法管辖区的不同法人实体控制。相关的解密密钥被分成几部分，并且永远不会与它们保护的数据保存在同一位置。因此，需要来自不同司法管辖区的多项法院命令才能迫使我们放弃任何数据。 […] To this day, we have disclosed 0 bytes of user data to third parties, including governments.

As a result, investigation after investigation finds that Telegram is a significant vector for the spread of CSAM. (To take only the most recent example, here's one from India's Decode last month , which like others found that criminals often advertise their wares on Instagram and direct buyers to Telegram to complete their purchases.) [...]

“Telegram is another level,” Brian Fishman, Meta's former anti-terrorism chief, wrote in a post on Threads . “It has been the key hub for ISIS for a decade. It tolerates CSAM. Its ignored reasonable [law enforcement] engagement for YEARS. It's not 'light' content moderation; it's a different approach entirely.

From the Ben Thompson piece yesterday that Newton links to above, is this description of just how unusual Telegram's “secret chats” are:

That is why “encryption” in the context of messaging means end-to-end encryption; this means that your messages are encrypted on your device and can only ever be decrypted and thus read by your intended recipient. Telegram does support this with “Secret Chats”, but these are not the default. Moreover, Telegram's implementation has a lot of oddities, including some non-standard encryption techniques, the fact that secret chats can only be between two devices (not two accounts, so you can't access a secret chat started on your phone from your computer), and that both users have to be online at the same time to initiate a secret chat (I'll come back to these oddities in a moment).

That's seemingly where we're headed. Everyone alive today has grown up in a world where you can't believe everything you read. Now we need to adapt to a world where that applies just as equally to photos and videos. Trusting the sources of what we believe is becoming more important than ever.

The same was true last year, and the year before that, and the year before that.

The single biggest culprit in breaches continues to be weak and stolen credentials. The 2024 DBIR found that “use of stolen credentials” is the number one initial action during a breach, and that credentials are the number one way attackers gain access in non-error, non-misuse breaches, followed by phishing and vulnerability exploits. This needs to change, and the 2024 DBIR offers a clear look at where we're falling short and where we go from here. entry.title: Pavel Durov, CEO of Telegram, Arrested in France
entry.content:
Reuters:

Pavel Durov, the Russian-born billionaire founder and owner of the Telegram messaging app, was arrested at Le Bourget airport outside Paris shortly after landing on a private jet late on Saturday and placed in custody, three sources told Reuters.

The arrest of the 39-year-old technology billionaire prompted on Sunday a warning from Moscow to Paris that he should be accorded his rights and criticism from X owner Elon Musk who said that free speech in Europe was under attack.

Such a warning is particularly rich coming from Russia so soon after the negotiated release of Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich.

Durov, who has dual French and United Arab Emirates citizenship, was arrested as part of a preliminary police investigation into allegedly allowing a wide range of crimes due to a lack of moderators on Telegram and a lack of cooperation with police, a third French police source说。

I don't yet have enough information to form an opinion on this arrest, but I will emphasize one point. There's a reaction going around that this is ridiculous because Telegram is “encrypted” and thus can't be moderated so arresting Durov for failing to moderate Telegram is a backdoor way of arresting him for providing encrypted communication. This is the result of a yearslong propaganda campaign by Telegram to describe itself using adjectives like “encrypted” and “secure”.它不是。 But the propaganda campaign has been extraordinarily successful .

Here's Signal founder Moxie Marlinspike back in February 2022, who, say what you will about Signal and the Signal Foundation, knows his shit about actual end-to-end encryption:

Telegram is the most popular messenger in urban Ukraine. After a decade of misleading marketing and press, most ppl there believe it's an “encrypted app”

The reality is the opposite-TG is by default a cloud database w/ a plaintext copy of every msg everyone has ever sent/recvd.

One-on-one chats in Telegram are not encrypted by default and group chats never are. Telegram employees have access to every single message ever sent to every group.

So, given how widely used Telegram is — perhaps especially in Ukraine — you can see why Russia is upset that Durov was arrested.

When the crowd members in the United Center first chanted, “Thank you, Joe! Thank you, Joe!” on Monday night, President Biden looked down, fought back tears and soaked in the admiration.

Fuck Peter Baker. What utter bullshit the word “involuntary” plays in that lede. Of course it was voluntary. Joe Biden is the President of the United States and is comfortable with the power that title affords. He was, even after his disastrous debate performance, only a few points behind in the polls. It was his call and his call alone to step aside — for the sake of his party, and more importantly, for the sake of the country he so obviously loves. And it's now obvious he made the right call.

Very few presidents have ever been faced with such a clear decision between the good of the nation and the drive of their personal ambition. Biden's ambition is legendary. Biden's response to this moment was heroic.

The Times can give Peter Baker as much ink as they want as a columnist. But they should stop calling him a “reporter”. He's nothing of the sort, and hasn't been for a long time.

The catch:

One big reason: Gemini Live works entirely in the cloud, not locally on a device. Google says it's working on ways for the new assistant to control phone functions and other Google apps.

It's a fascinating — but unsurprising — strategic and culture difference that Apple Intelligence runs largely on device, and completely privately even when going to the cloud, and Google Gemini is currently only in the cloud, and with nothing like Apple's Private Cloud Compute. To be clear, Google's new lineup of Pixel 9 phones perform a lot of “AI” features on device, but not the Gemini voice assistant.

★

Playing that game of whack-a-mole monthly instead of weekly is absolutely an improvement. But I still think there ought to be a way to grant a properly notarized app permanent permission.

entry.summary: The Mac is a platform where you need to be able to shoot yourself in the foot.
entry.content:
Back in the day, on classic Mac OS, there were no “privileges” for software. If you launched an app, or installed a system extension, that software just did what it wanted. Something as ( seemingly ) innocuous as a game or as necessarily powerful as a disk formatting utility just ... ran. If that disk utility had a bug that overwrote every byte of your startup disk with zeroes, well, tough luck. If you were unfortunate enough to install malicious software that spread like a virus, well, even tougher luck. That sounds awful, but in practice, it was fine. I've been using a Mac since 1991 and I don't recall ever once — not once — having a problem with malware or scamware. 1

那是很久以前的事了。

Such a laissez-faire approach to software privileges obviously wouldn't fly today. I want most applications on my Mac to run within a sandbox. I want applications to require explicit permission to access the camera and microphone, or to capture the content of my display. I want applications to be cryptographically signed by known developers and notarized by Apple by default. But I also want to be able to grant trusted applications non-sandboxed access to my entire file system, access to cameras and microphones, and the ability to capture my screen.

I posted a spate of links this week about how the anti-malware/anti-scamware protections in MacOS are increasingly crossing the line from “this is a reasonable balance” to “this is infuriating”. It really is turning into exactly what Apple once mocked .

The Mac is a platform where you need to be able to shoot yourself in the foot. Increased protections that make it less likely that you'll shoot yourself in the foot are, obviously, a good idea. Many of them are downright necessary. But such protections are only undeniably good ideas when they don't get in the way of sophisticated users using software that requires a high level of system privileges. Then they become a trade-off. There are some power users who've been annoyed every step of the way as Apple has increased such protections in MacOS, but I think, until recently, Apple has managed this balance well. MacOS, on the whole, has been welcoming and safe for unsophisticated users while remaining powerful and efficient for experts. But in recent years MacOS has clearly started slipping down the slippery slope of being too protective.

It's good to be reminded of the software you have installed that requests, or outright requires, access to private data and sensitive hardware APIs. It's very good to be alerted to any software you might have installed that has acquired such permissions without your knowledge or recollection. (Like, say, if an abusive partner has installed some sort of monitoring software unbeknownst to you.) But it's infuriating to play whack-a-mole to dismiss a barrage of permission prompts to confirm the same permissions you've previously granted to the same software, and it's even worse when you need to dig three or four levels deep into System Settings to do it.

Consider real-world power tools. No one wants to get hurt. For sure, no one wants to lose a finger. But serious tool users still have holes to drill, wood to cut, and nails to hammer. There's a fascinating saga around the company SawStop , which invented a technology for table saws that uses capacitive sensors to prevent saws from slicing through fingers (or, say, for demo purposes, hot dogs ). As of a decade ago, in the US alone, over 4,000 fingers were sliced off in table saw accidents annually. That's a lot of fingers. SawStop's technology prevents almost all such accidents. But also: it doesn't make table saws worse for cutting wood . The company has a FAQ about cutting wet or “green” wood :

SawStop saws cut most wet wood without a problem. However, if the wood is very green or wet (for example, wet enough to spray a mist when cutting), or if the wood is both wet and pressure treated, then the wood may be sufficiently conductive to activate the brake. If you are unsure whether the material you need to cut is conductive, you can make test cuts using Bypass Mode to determine if it will activate the safety system's brake. The red light on the control box will flash to indicate conductivity. If the material is conductive, you can choose to operate the saw in Bypass Mode which will disengage the saw's safety system's brake feature and allow you to continue cutting the material.

This sounds like exactly the right balance for MacOS — a balance MacOS until recently had achieved. Safety by default, but don't get in the way of power users doing their jobs. And when the user needs an override for the safety features, there is an override, and the situation will make clear to the user that needing to use the override is justified by the safety concerns. MacOS is veering into the territory of power users needing to flip override switches all the time .

At the two extremes of the Mac's user base are gullible technically unsophisticated naifs, and skeptical expert power users. It's fair for Apple to present some protections that aren't necessary for expert power users, in the name of bolstering the guardrails for the technically unsophisticated. But at a certain point, a hammer needs to hammer whatever it strikes, and sometimes, alas, that's the user's thumb. That's the Mac. It's a Unix workstation that's friendly enough to be used by the mass market. It is not an appliance intended to prevent any possible malware or scamware from running.

Apple makes such appliances. They run iOS. I'd go so far as to say that one problem facing the Mac has nothing to do with the Mac itself but instead is a downstream effect of the iPad's weaknesses. I believe in the 1984 slogan that the Mac is “the computer for the rest of us”, where “the rest of us” is very much inclusive of non-expert users. But there's a certain point of unsophistication and okey-doke gullibility where the Mac becomes an inappropriate platform for some users. There are many construction-professional power tools that shouldn't be used by non-expert users, too.

Computers are such an essential part of the modern world — and almost everyone's daily lives — that computers-that-work-like-computers aren't for everyone. The world needs locked-down can't-cut-your-fingers-off-no-matter-what-you-do platforms like the iPad. And Apple sells significantly more iPad units than Macs. But any Mac user who isn't sufficiently served by the anti-malware/scamware protections already in MacOS shouldn't be using a Mac at all. They should be using iPads, or something else similarly locked-down, instead. Some of these users are using Macs instead of iPads out of ignorance. Their technical needs could be met by an iPad but they don't know it. (They are, by definition, technically unsophisticated.) But surely some of them know they'd prefer to be using an iPad instead of a Mac but can't, because an iPad can't do one or more things they need to do, or run software they need to run.

Power tools and user-safety features aren't mutually exclusive. But they need to be in balance. Apple is clearly losing that balance with MacOS, and I think a big part of that is the iPad's weaknesses tipping the scale.

  1. That viruses, malware, and scamware weren't significant problems for classic Mac OS users doesn't mean such things didn't exist. There was, in fact, a spate of viruses in the late 1980s and early 1990s , which were splendidly addressed by a freeware anti-virus system extension called Disinfectant, by John Norstad . But on the whole, the entire two-decade era of classic Mac OS passed without much malware. Part of that was by design, part by security-through-relative-obscurity, and part, perhaps, by good luck. ↩︎

entry.summary: Apple's success with services is no more a distraction from their core business than their success with their own chain of retail stores has been.
entry.content:
Jason Snell, “ Existential Thoughts About Apple's Reliance on Services Revenue ”:

The intersection of hardware and software has been Apple's home address since the 1970s. And yet, a few years ago, Apple updated its marketing language and began to refer to Apple's secret sauce as the combination of “hardware, software, and services.” [...]

Last quarter, Apple made about $22 billion in profit from products and $18 billion from Services. It's the closest those two lines have ever come to each other.

This is what was buzzing in the back of my head as I was going over all the numbers on Thursday. We're not quite there yet, but it's hard to imagine that there won't be a quarter in the next year or so in which Apple reports more total profit on Services than on products.

When that happens, is Apple still a products company? Or has it crossed some invisible line?

What a great column from Snell. One way to look at it — as Snell points out in the first paragraph quoted above — is that Apple has always been a two-sided coin. They are the company that best exemplifies Alan Kay's adage : “People who are really serious about software should make their own hardware.” Apple has always been like one of those optical illusions that looks like one thing at first, but looks like another if you stare at it for a few seconds . A hardware company that makes great software. A software company that makes great hardware.

Coins only have two sides though. If services constitute a new third dimension for the company, and we carry this analogy through, it's like a coin whose edge just keeps getting thicker. If the edge gets thick enough, it's no longer a coin — it's something else. A stick or a baton.

But another way to look at it is that services are just another form of software. Software that runs not on the personal computing devices Apple sells to customers, but which run on servers in the cloud. And, importantly, is sold to users via lucrative recurring subscriptions. Content often isn't what we think of as software (like say music, movies, and TV shows) but content from the App Store is. But the key is that it's all stuff that the users of Apple's devices consume on those devices. Apple's core business is designing, engineering, producing, and selling those devices. Services are just a huge, and growing, part of what users do and consume on those devices.

To extend Kay's axiom for today's world, I suspect Apple's leadership sees things this way: People who are really serious about device platforms should make their own services. Viewed that way, Apple's success with services is no more a distraction from their core business than their success with their own chain of retail stores has been. It's just a necessary evolution.

Eric Seufert, on Threads :

Regarding Taboola's partnership with Apple: I've seen people claim that this is somehow hypocritical from a privacy perspective, assuming that Taboola's somewhat obnoxious, clickbait-style ads must invasively target user profiles and browsing histories.

他们不这样做。 They are targeted entirely contextually.这就是重点。

Want brash, garish advertising plastered all over the web? Reject ads personalization. Want relevant, informed advertising? Embrace ads personalization.

If you told me that the ads in Apple News have been sold by Taboola for the last few years, I'd have said, “Oh, that makes sense.” Because the ads in Apple News — at least the ones I see 1 — already look like chumbox Taboola ads. Even worse, they're incredibly repetitious.

这是一个例子。 Today a friend sent me a link to an article at Rolling Stone. The article was behind a paywall on their website, so I used the Share sheet to open the article in Apple News. (Rolling Stone is one of many publications included with a News+ subscription, which I get through the Apple One bundle. This is pretty much the only reason I use Apple News — for reading stories that are paywalled on the web.) I made screen recordings showing me scrolling through the entire article, twice . I got different ads each time, but on both page loads there was at least one ad shown four times, and at least one other ad shown twice. That's a lot of ads, and a lot of repetition.

And, by sheer coincidence, on the web Rolling Stone is a Taboola partner. Here's a screenshot of the box of “suggested stories” chum that Taboola offered. It's pretty much exactly the sort of stuff I see in the ads on Apple News.

So while I don't think it's good news that Apple is partnering with Taboola, I don't expect it to make any discernible difference in the ad quality or frequency. Maybe it will improve the variety?

  1. And, for what it's worth (which might not be much), I do have “Personalized Ads” enabled in Settings → Privacy & Security → Apple Advertising. So I should be seeing the best ads Apple has to offer in Apple News. The half-dozen ads for Bellagio and MGM Resorts that you see in the second screen recording I made of that Rolling Stone article do seem personalized — I've read a couple of articles this week commemorating the closing of The Mirage . Bellagio is effectively Mirage 2.0 (and Wynn and Encore are 3.0). ↩︎

entry.summary: SMS wasn't dying, but it was slowly fading away, and should have been left for things like automated “your table is ready” notifications from restaurants. RCS is just going to give carrier-based messaging new legs that it shouldn't have gotten.
entry.content:
Here's a hot take: last week's news of a massive AT&T breach revealing the phone call and text messaging records of all AT&T customers for six months in 2022 exemplifies why RCS is a terrible protocol that ought not exist, and why it's a mistake that Apple is adding support for it to iOS 18 this year.

The pro-RCS argument is that it improves upon SMS by adding support for much larger image and video attachments, as well as niceties like typing indicators. It really is just like SMS but better, which makes it seem, on the surface, like a no-brainer that all cell phone platforms should support it. In this view, the only reason for Apple's yearslong refusal to support RCS was to maintain a maximum feature gap between iMessage (which, famously, is exclusive to Apple's devices) and carrier-based messaging. In day-to-day use people can't see that iMessage is fully end-to-end encrypted, but everyone can plainly see that images and videos sent over SMS/MMS look like shit. So it looks like nothing but pure spite that Apple refused, for years, to support RCS.

But the argument against RCS is strong and simple: it doesn't support end-to-end encryption. The only new messaging platforms that should gain any traction are those that not only support E2EE, but that require it . Messaging and audio/video calls should only work through E2EE. That's true for iMessage and FaceTime.

SMS and traditional telephone voice calls lack any encryption at all, but they're firmly established. Just like email. But anything new should only be supported if it's fundamentally based on E2EE. The RCS spec offers no message encryption at all. Google has implemented its own encryption for RCS, but, that's a proprietary implementation that only works for messages sent between users who are all using Google's own Messages app. From Google's “Messages End-to-End Encryption Overview” :

In order to store and exchange user public keys like identity keys and prekeys, we need to have a central key server. Unlike the RCS messaging servers, the key server is currently only hosted by Google.

Perhaps, someday, the RCS spec will support an open standard for E2EE. I'm not holding my breath for that. For one thing, industry consortiums tend not to produce good solutions to hard problems, and an open standard for E2EE messaging is a very hard problem. Maybe impossible. Someone has to handle key exchange and management, but who would that be in an open standard? Then there's the politics: law enforcement agencies the world over will pressure carriers against that. As I reported back in February , the primary reason Apple changed course on supporting RCS is that it's mandated in China. The Chinese government surely loves RCS because it isn't encrypted.

That's not unique to China or other authoritarian dictatorships. Even in the West, law enforcement and spy agencies love the fact that telephone voice calls and cellular text messages are unencrypted. We don't know how much they record and keep, but it's a known fact that the NSA has black boxes installed at the carriers' call centers, and the safest bet is that they record and store all of it. But even if you trust law enforcement agencies to handle this sensitive data securely, it's clear, from this latest data breach alone, that the carriers themselves cannot be trusted. They're inept. They always have been inept . And my money says they always will be.

But even if, somehow, a future version of the RCS spec supports E2EE, what about older devices that only support today's non-encrypted version of RCS? Even if RCS eventually supports E2EE — which, again, I doubt — such support will surely be optional, not mandatory, because RCS has already shipped and is in widespread use on Android without encryption. That's why messaging platforms should be built around E2EE from the start. It's difficult to mandate E2EE on a platform that already supports unencrypted messaging. RCS should have been exclusively E2EE; instead, the standard offers no encryption at all.

Carrier-based messaging was best left as a legacy protocol. SMS wasn't dying, but it was slowly fading away, and should have been left for things like automated “your table is ready” notifications from restaurants. RCS is just going to give carrier-based messaging new legs that it shouldn't have gotten.

Another thing that sucks about carrier-based messaging is that it requires a device with an active SIM card from a carrier. Yes, you can send and receive SMS from a Mac or iPad with Text Message Forwarding , but you need the iPhone to do the forwarding. If you power down (or worse, lose) your iPhone, your Mac and iPad will no longer be able to send or receive SMS messages — and I presume that will be true for RCS as well . Whereas with modern messaging platforms like iMessage, Signal, and WhatsApp, devices like PCs and tablets can serve as clients without a phone. 1

There is, admittedly, a good argument in favor of RCS. Basically, that phone carrier messaging is now and always will be a universally accessible form of communication. Effectively , everyone who is online has a cell phone, and those phones can all send and receive SMS. Because carrier-based messaging isn't going away, this argument goes, it ought to be made as good as possible, and RCS — despite its deficiencies — is clearly better than SMS. Therefore RCS ought to be supported by all mobile devices, including iOS. Here's Andy Ihnatko, in a discussion with me on Threads back in November :

Carrier-based messaging on a pre-installed messaging app might seem irrelevant to many of us. But it serves and suffices. And the process of discovery, selection, and installation of a different service — and getting your entire social circle on board with it — is deathly for so many people.

“If I know their phone number, I can send them a message or a photo” is a world-beater of a feature for the average user. This is why such apps should be as muscular as feasibly possible.

Ihnatko is right, but only if you believe that carrier-based messaging should remain the baseline.我不知道。 And it's also a US-centric viewpoint. In most countries around the world, platforms like WhatsApp, Line, and Facebook Messenger serve that role, as the baseline “everyone has it” messaging platform — and those countries are better for it. I prefer iMessage, personally, for multiple reasons, but iMessage is fundamentally limited from serving that “everyone has it” baseline role by Apple's decision not to ship an Android client. Eddy Cue doesn't lose many arguments but he lost that one . All of the effort spent pushing Apple to support RCS would have been better spent pushing Apple to ship iMessage for Android. And without a supported iMessage client for Android, that role ought to go to WhatsApp, not RCS. WhatsApp is free, secure, and works equally well on all phones.

Meta knows this , and clearly smells the opportunity . Does Apple?

  1. Two notes on this. First: security researcher Tommy Mysk recently publicized some serious issues with how Signal's Mac client stores data locally, especially the fact that it stores its encryption key in a plain text file readable by any app on your Mac. This is not a defect in the Signal protocol, which is fully end-to-end encrypted, and arguably the gold standard for privacy. The problem with Signal's desktop apps is that they're storing information locally, without protection, outside the endpoints of “E2EE”. As Mysk proved, you can just copy Signal's data folder from one Mac (that is properly signed into Signal) to another Mac (say, an attacker's machine) and that second machine will be able to send and receive messages without the user being able to detect that an unauthorized machine has access to their account. Signal claims to be addressing this flaw in a future version now in beta testing.

    Second: Meta's companywide aversion to developing native iPad apps includes WhatsApp. At least with Threads and Instagram, they allow the iPhone apps to run on iPadOS in letterboxed compatibility mode. But as you can see in this screenshot (which also shows how the lack of a proper native iPad client for WhatsApp has created a cottage industry of sketchy third-party apps in the App Store that are presenting themselves as WhatsApp clients), the iPhone WhatsApp client can't even be installed on an iPad.这太令人恼火了。 Meta does have proper native iPad versions of the blue Facebook app and Messenger, so I suppose there's hope they'll ship a proper WhatsApp client for iPad eventually. ↩︎

entry.summary: Make them all say, as Trump himself did after a school shooting massacre in Iowa this year, that we “have to get over it, we have to move forward.”
entry.content:
Josh Marshall, writing at Talking Points Memo :

Political violence and especially electoral violence strike at the heart of the open, free and democratic choice-making upon which our civic democratic system and the legitimacy of its choices are based. We must condemn it in every instance as well as expressing our personal sympathy for its victims. We do so not to box check some vague concept of civility or comity but because it strikes at the taproot of civil peace. It is equally not a license to squelch political speech or in this case threaten or intimidate those calling attention to the real and profound dangers of Donald Trump returning to the White House. We are already seeing this attempt in the making.

Political violence is abhorrent, and as Marshall aptly notes, strikes at the heart of the very concept of democracy. Words cannot express strongly enough the feelings that an event like yesterday's evokes, no matter which side of the political spectrum we're on. We call many things “unacceptable” but an assassination attempt is more than that. It's sick, and, correctly, makes us feel sick. It's like how our bodies revolt when we consume poison. An assassination attempt is poison to the body politic.

But only one of the candidates in this election has ever incited political violence. That candidate is Donald Trump, particularly and especially on January 6, 2021 . Only one candidate has ever mocked and cracked jokes about a near-miss assassination attempt against one of his political adversaries. That candidate is Donald Trump, who ( along with his son ) has repeatedly mocked Nancy Pelosi's husband Paul after an unhinged lunatic, asking “Where is Nancy?” , broke into their home and bashed Paul Pelosi's head with a hammer, fracturing his skull to an extent that required surgery.

Donald Trump wasn't an inch away from assassination because of Democratic rhetoric against his threat to democracy. He is a threat to democracy. He threatened democracy on national television. He has repeated, literally hundreds of times over the last three and a half years, thatthe fairest election this nation has ever held was “rigged” because he lost. Ask him today and he'll say the same. Give Trump credit: he fully admits that the only election results he will accept are results that declare him the winner. But that, quite literally, is a threat to our democracy. He tried to remain in office after losing, by almost the exact same Electoral College margin he declared “ a massive landslide victory ” when he won in 2016, by overthrowing the duly elected government of the United States. Ask him today if he should still be in the White House.

Do not accept, not even at this fraught moment, the claims of anyone blaming yesterday on Democrats describing Trump as a threat to democracy. Saying so is not even on the spectrum of hyperbole. We saw what we saw after the 2020 election, and especially on January 6.

Do not fret, either, that yesterday's event somehow cedes the election to Trump, on the grounds that he survived and projected strength. The side that wants a strongman was already voting for him. They're the same people who claimed, wrongly , that being convicted of 34 felonies somehow helped him electorally. This is , no question, an indelible image and a photo for the ages. But Teddy Roosevelt was shot campaigning in 1912 — and unlike Trump took the stage to deliver his speech after taking the bullet — and lost the election by 347 Electoral College votes (an actual landslide) to Woodrow Wilson. Running for president for the third time in 1972, virulently racist Alabama governor George Wallace was shot , leaving him paralyzed. Wallace lost the primary. Gerald Ford survived not just one but two shooting attempts within 17 days in 1975. Ford wore a bulletproof trench coat in public for the remainder of his term. He lost the 1976 election to Jimmy Carter. ( It was quite close .)

The truth is that our nation, great though it is in so many ways, has a horrific history of political violence and a seemingly innate obsession with firearms. Four presidents have been assassinated in office — Lincoln in 1865, Garfield in 1881, McKinley in 1901, and Kennedy in 1963 — all by gunshots. Three more — Roosevelt, Reagan (who nearly died), and now Trump — have been wounded by gunshots. And there have been numerous other failed attempts , including a nut who fired shots into the White House during Barack Obama's first term in 2011 .

Also, yesterday's events will be old news by election day. There are 113 days until November 5. It's been 129 days since Joe Biden's strong State of the Union speech. Does that State of the Union feel recent to you today? That's how old yesterday's shooting will feel when we vote.

So here is what the Democrats should do. Tomorrow morning Chuck Schumer should put on the floor of the Senate a law mandating strict background checks for all gun purchases. Perhaps tie it to a reinstitution of the 1994 assault weapons ban that Republicans allowed to expire in 2004. Give it a name like the “Anti Political and School Violence Act”. Make Republicans shoot it down. Make them say, as Trump himself did after a school shooting massacre in Iowa this year, that we “ have to get over it, we have to move forward .” It's not just an outrage when your right-wing authoritarian hero gets his ear nicked by an assassin's bullet. It's an outrage when anyone is shot by a nut with a gun.

Make them say it. See how that flies.
